author: Aditi R
text:
While their longevity is increasing, thanks to medical care, their support systems are vanishing

On Saturday, 72-year-old Amaravathi lodged a complaint at the Pattabiram police station that she feared danger from her son and sought protection.

Amaravathi went to the police after her son Anand and his wife allegedly threatened to kill her. She said that she was subjected to verbal abuse every day. “It takes a lot for aged parents to come out and lodge a complaint. She has been bold enough; they usually take it all and bear the pain silently,” said V. Sivakumar, joint director of HelpAge India. Every day, the organisation receives at least two calls from aggrieved senior citizens seeking help to deal with loneliness or abuse from their children. In a month, the number easily touches 40.

“In most cases, it is financial crisis, fight over property or their children being unable to afford their stay,” said R. Muthukrishnan, psychologist and manager at HelpAge helpline. “While their longevity is increasing, thanks to medical care, their support systems are vanishing,” he said.

According to the 2011 Census, the elderly constitute 10.4 per cent of the total population of the State as against 8.6 per cent in the country.

A study conducted by the United Nations Population Fund (UNFPA) the same year states that more than half of the elderly in Tamil Nadu do not have any personal income.
title: Helpline gets two calls a day from senior citizens
